stem: A 38-year-old client has sustained full-thickness circumferential burns to the left arm. Based on the documentation in the Burn Unit & Distal Perfusion Log tab, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Acute loss of distal perfusion in a burned extremity.
Background: Flash burn from industrial explosion. Circumferential injury to the entire forearm.
Assessment: Skin is 'leathery' and tight. Hand is cool and pale.
Recommendation: Immediate surgical decompression.

tabs.title: Perfusion & Tissue Status
tabs.content:
Assessment ItemCurrent FindingInterpretation
Distal Pulse (Radial)Absent to palpation; Weak Doppler 'hiss'Severe Obstruction
Skin ConsistencyEschar is non-compliant and restrictiveChest/Arm constriction
Capillary Refill> 5 secondsPoor perfusion
MovementInability to flex fingersNerve/Muscle ischemia

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: BP 132/84, HR 128, RR 24. Client is in severe pain.

actionOptions.text: Prepare for a bedside Escharotomy (Incision through the burn)
Use a Doppler ultrasound to reassess pulses every 15 minutes
Apply high-pressure elastic bandages to stabilize the skin
Place the arm in a dependant position below the level of the heart

parameterOptions.text: Pulse quality (Doppler vs Palpation) and sensory changes
Respiratory effort (if the eschar is on the chest)
Daily measurement of fasting serum glucose
Presence of a positive Babinski sign

rationale.correct: Circumferential burns (c2) as they heal create a tough, non-elastic leathery tissue called 'eschar'. As the tissue underneath swells from the burn inflammatory response, the eschar acts as a tourniquet, cutting off circulation. This is essentially 'Burn-Induced Compartment Syndrome'. The priority is an Escharotomy (a1) to release the pressure. Assessing pulses via Doppler (a2) is critical because manual palpation is often impossible through charred skin. Parameters include the pulse (p1) and respiratory expansion (p2) (if the burn were on the chest).
clinicalPearls: Circumferential = Major Warning Sign. If the burn goes all the way around a limb or the chest, it's an emergency.
An Escharotomy goes through the eschar (skin) only. A Fasciotomy goes through the deep muscle fascia.
Successful escharotomy shows 'Immediate return of pink color and distal pulses.'

questionTrap.howToOvercome: In burns, the bottleneck is the SKIN (Eschar). Escharotomy is the first step. If that doesn't work, then a Fasciotomy might be needed, but start with the skin.

mnemonic.title: Restrictive Eschar
mnemonic.expansion: R-Radial pulse gone. E-Escharotomy required. S-Sensation lost.
